trial_identification.studytitle: Single deepest pocket versus amniotic fluid index to improve perinatal outcomes
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Single deepest vertical pocket versus amniotic fluid index for pregnant women to improve perinatal outcomes

interventions.interventions: Single deepest vertical pocket method for assessment of amniotic fluid volume using real time ultrasound. The sonographer measures the largest vertical diameter of a fluid pocket (not containing small fetal parts or loops of umbilical cord). The assessment will be performed at least one weekly from recruitment till delivery. The absence of a single 2 x 1 cm pocket will indicate decreased fluid volume
interventions.comparator: amniotic fluid index method for assessment of amniotic fluid volume using real time ultrasound. The sonographer divides the uterine cavity into four quadrants. In each quadrant, the largest vertical diameter of a fluid pocket (not containing small fetal parts or loops of umbilical cord) is measured. The sum of these four measures provides a single value for the AFI. The assessment will be performed at least one weekly from recruitment till delivery. AFI <5 will indicate decreased fluid volume

primaryOutcome.outcome: umbilical cord pH <7.1 in an arterial blood sample after delivery of the fetus

secondaryOutcome.outcome: length of stay in the neonatal intensive care unit as monitored by health care professionals
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: it will be monitored for up until 4 weeks postpartum.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: neonatal admission to neonatal intensive care unit as indicated by health care professionals
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: it will be monitored for up until 4 weeks postpartum.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: pregnant women in the third trimester

trial_design.sequence: computer random number genrator using graphpad software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Amniotic fluid provides a supportive and protective environment for fetal development during pregnancy. A decreased amniotic fluid volume (oligohydramnios) can occur because of intrauterine growth restriction, pre-eclampsia or prolonged pregnancy. Many caregivers practice planned delivery by induction of labor or caesarean section after diagnosis of decreased amniotic fluid volume at term, to prevent an adverse pregnancy outcome. Ultrasonography is non-invasive and is used widely for the follow up of pregnancy. It can be used to determine amniotic fluid volume by measuring either the amniotic fluid index or single deepest vertical pocket. The aim of the current randomized clinical trial (RCT) is to compare the use of the amniotic fluid index with the single deepest vertical pocket measurement during pregnancy to prevent adverse pregnancy outcome.
